Selecting academic fields of study

The first step in studying MIDFIELD undergraduate student records is selecting the academic fields to study.

Academic programs are encoded in cip, a data frame of program codes and names of academic fields of study from the Classification of Instructional Programs (CIP) standardized by the US Department of Education.

filter_cip() is the function for filtering the cip data frame to obtain the desired programs.

library(midfieldr)

# other packages used in the vignette
library(dplyr) 
library(magrittr)
library(stringr)
library(knitr)

For the cip help page, type ?cip.

Usage

filter_cip(series = NULL, data = NULL)

With NULL arguments, filter_cip() returns the cip data frame.

filter_cip()
#> # A tibble: 1,544 x 6
#>    CIP2                                                    PGRM2  CIP4
#>   <chr>                                                    <chr> <chr>
#> 1    01 Agriculture/Agricultural Operations and Related Sciences  0100
#> 2    01 Agriculture/Agricultural Operations and Related Sciences  0101
#> 3    01 Agriculture/Agricultural Operations and Related Sciences  0101
#> 4    01 Agriculture/Agricultural Operations and Related Sciences  0101
#> 5    01 Agriculture/Agricultural Operations and Related Sciences  0101
#> 6    01 Agriculture/Agricultural Operations and Related Sciences  0101
#> # ... with 1,538 more rows, and 3 more variables: PGRM4 <chr>, CIP6 <chr>,
#> #   PGRM6 <chr>

Conditions that cause an error:

  • data not a data frame
  • data variables different from cip variables (column names)

Directly specifying the CIP codes

The CIP taxonomy is organized on three levels: a 2-digit series, a 4-digit series, and a 6-digit series. Assigning a character vector of any of these series to the series argument of filter_cip() yields a data frame of all associated codes and program names at all three levels.

  • If the series includes 1, 3, or 5-digit partial codes, filter_cip() returns all codes that start with those partial codes.
  • Invalid codes—and valid codes not in the midfieldr cip dataset—are silently ignored.

Specifying 6-digit codes yields a data frame with a row for each 6-digit code.

# 6-digit example
df <- filter_cip(series = c("140802", "140803"))
kable(df)
CIP2 PGRM2 CIP4 PGRM4 CIP6 PGRM6
14 Engineering 1408 Civil Engineering 140802 Geotechnical Engineering
14 Engineering 1408 Civil Engineering 140803 Structural Engineering

Specifying 4-digit codes yields a data frame with as many rows as there are 6-digit codes in the 4-digit groups.

# 4-digit example
df <- filter_cip(series = c("1407", "1408"))
kable(df)
CIP2 PGRM2 CIP4 PGRM4 CIP6 PGRM6
14 Engineering 1407 Chemical Engineering 140701 Chemical Engineering
14 Engineering 1407 Chemical Engineering 140702 Chemical and Biomolecular Engineering
14 Engineering 1407 Chemical Engineering 140799 Chemical Engineering - Other
14 Engineering 1408 Civil Engineering 140801 Civil Engineering - General
14 Engineering 1408 Civil Engineering 140802 Geotechnical Engineering
14 Engineering 1408 Civil Engineering 140803 Structural Engineering
14 Engineering 1408 Civil Engineering 140804 Transportation and Highway Engineering
14 Engineering 1408 Civil Engineering 140805 Water Resources Engineering
14 Engineering 1408 Civil Engineering 140899 Civil Engineering - Other

The 2-digit series represent the most general groupings of related programs. Here, the result includes all History codes and programs.

# 2-digit example
df <- filter_cip("54")
kable(df)
CIP2 PGRM2 CIP4 PGRM4 CIP6 PGRM6
54 History 5401 History 540101 History - General
54 History 5401 History 540102 American History (United States)
54 History 5401 History 540103 European History
54 History 5401 History 540104 History and Philosophy of Science and Technology
54 History 5401 History 540105 Public/Applied History and Archival Administration
54 History 5401 History 540106 Asian History
54 History 5401 History 540107 Canadian History
54 History 5401 History 540108 Military History
54 History 5401 History 540199 History - Other

The series argument can include any combination of 2, 4, and 6-digit codes.

# a series with 2, 4, and 6-digits specified
df <- filter_cip(c("24", "4102", "450202"))
kable(df)
CIP2 PGRM2 CIP4 PGRM4 CIP6 PGRM6
24 Liberal Arts and Sciences/General Studies and Humanities 2401 Liberal Arts and Sciences/General Studies Humanities 240101 Liberal Arts and Sciences/Liberal Studies
24 Liberal Arts and Sciences/General Studies and Humanities 2401 Liberal Arts and Sciences/General Studies Humanities 240102 General Studies
24 Liberal Arts and Sciences/General Studies and Humanities 2401 Liberal Arts and Sciences/General Studies Humanities 240103 Humanities/Humanistic Studies
24 Liberal Arts and Sciences/General Studies and Humanities 2401 Liberal Arts and Sciences/General Studies Humanities 240199 Liberal Arts and Sciences/General Studies and Humanities - Other
41 Science Technologies/Technicians 4102 Nuclear and Industrial Radiologic Technologies/Technicians 410204 Industrial Radiologic Technology/Technician
41 Science Technologies/Technicians 4102 Nuclear and Industrial Radiologic Technologies/Technicians 410205 Nuclear/Nuclear Power Technology/Technician
41 Science Technologies/Technicians 4102 Nuclear and Industrial Radiologic Technologies/Technicians 410299 Nuclear and Industrial Radiologic Technologies/Technicians - Other
45 Social Sciences 4502 Anthropology 450202 Physical Anthropology

A series assigned as a numerical sequence is coerced to characters.

# series as a sequence
df <- filter_cip(series = seq(540102, 540110, 1))
kable(df)
CIP2 PGRM2 CIP4 PGRM4 CIP6 PGRM6
54 History 5401 History 540102 American History (United States)
54 History 5401 History 540103 European History
54 History 5401 History 540104 History and Philosophy of Science and Technology
54 History 5401 History 540105 Public/Applied History and Archival Administration
54 History 5401 History 540106 Asian History
54 History 5401 History 540107 Canadian History
54 History 5401 History 540108 Military History

Invalid codes in the sequence, e.g., 540109 and 540110, are silently ignored.

Using a previous result as a data argument

A data frame produced by filter_cip() can be used as the data argument in a subsequent use of filter_cip().

df1 <- filter_cip("49")

Suppose, after viewing the full “49” series above we decide we only need the “4903” subset. We can use the data frame df1 from above as the data argument.

# use a previous result as a data argument
df2 <- filter_cip(series = "4903", data = df1)
kable(df2)
CIP2 PGRM2 CIP4 PGRM4 CIP6 PGRM6
49 Transportation and Materials Moving Services 4903 Marine Transportation Services 490303 Commercial Fishing
49 Transportation and Materials Moving Services 4903 Marine Transportation Services 490304 Diver/Professional and Instructor
49 Transportation and Materials Moving Services 4903 Marine Transportation Services 490309 Marine Science/Merchant Marine Officer
49 Transportation and Materials Moving Services 4903 Marine Transportation Services 490399 Marine Transportation Services - Other

Specifying the CIP codes using named series

midfieldr includes several datasets of “named series”. A named series is a character vector of 6-digit CIP codes that belong to a group of programs such as Engineering, Physical Sciences, STEM, etc. For more information on the named series, data(package = "midfieldr") or ?named_series.

In use, the named series is the series argument in filter_cip().

# the engineering series
engr
#>  [1] "140101" "140102" "140201" "140301" "140401" "140501" "140601"
#>  [8] "140701" "140702" "140799" "140801" "140802" "140803" "140804"
#> [15] "140805" "140899" "140901" "140902" "140903" "140999" "141001"
#> [22] "141003" "141004" "141099" "141101" "141201" "141301" "141401"
#> [29] "141801" "141901" "142001" "142101" "142201" "142301" "142401"
#> [36] "142501" "142701" "142801" "143101" "143201" "143301" "143401"
#> [43] "143501" "143601" "143701" "143801" "143901" "144001" "144101"
#> [50] "144201" "144301" "144401" "144501" "149999"

engr_cip <- filter_cip(series = engr)
glimpse(engr_cip)
#> Observations: 54
#> Variables: 6
#> $ CIP2  <chr> "14", "14", "14", "14", "14", "14", "14", "14", "14", "1...
#> $ PGRM2 <chr> "Engineering", "Engineering", "Engineering", "Engineerin...
#> $ CIP4  <chr> "1401", "1401", "1402", "1403", "1404", "1405", "1406", ...
#> $ PGRM4 <chr> "Engineering/General", "Engineering/General", "Aerospace...
#> $ CIP6  <chr> "140101", "140102", "140201", "140301", "140401", "14050...
#> $ PGRM6 <chr> "Engineering - General", "Pre-Engineering", "Aerospace/A...
